segments.key_quote: King Yudhishthira fully supported Queen Draupadi's statements which were having all these wonderful characteristics.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the 49th verse of the 7th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, focusing on King Yudhishthira's support of Draupadi's statements, which embody dharma, justice, mercy, and lack of duplicity.
segments.transcript: In the previous session, I began discussing the 49th verse of the 7th chapter of the 1st canto of Bhagavatam. I could not complete it. I will continue. I will complete it in this session, the same 49th verse. I will read once again the 49th verse just for refreshing your memory. Suta Vacha Dharmam Nyayam Sakarunam Nirvyalekam Samam Mahat Raja Dharmasuto Ragnya Pratyanandad Vachodvijaha. The meaning of this verse is Suta Goswami is speaking to the Sayyiduna Misharanya, the Brahamanas. O Brahamanas, he is telling, he is addressing them and speaking to them. King Yudhishthira fully supported the statements of the queen. Who is the queen here? Draupadi, Queen Draupadi, which were in accordance with the principles of religion, Dharmam, and were justified, Nyayam, and were full of mercy, Sakarunam, Nirvyalekam, without duplicity. Sakarunam, Nirvyalekam, without duplicity. Samam, full of equity and Mahat, they were glorious.

segments.summary: The speaker explains that Yudhishthira knew the principles of religion and supported Draupadi's plea to spare Ashwathama, and discusses the importance of Dharmashastra and its relevance in Kali Yuga.
segments.transcript: So, King Yudhishthira fully supported Queen Draupadi's statements which were having all these wonderful characteristics. So, in the Purport, Srila Prabhupada says that Maharaja Yudhishthira was a son of Dharmaraja. So, he knew exactly what are the principles of religion and he supported Draupadi who was justified in telling Arjuna, don't kill Ashwathama even though he is a murderer of the five sons of Draupadi. Don't kill Ashwathama. So, what was the justification? That we have discussed earlier that Draupadi was making the statement or telling Arjuna, don't kill Ashwathama because she was conversant with the principles of religion. So, religion means here Dharma. Dharma means the eternal principles of our religion. That is what I mean by Dharmashastra. It is the intrinsic nature of service. So, such service has to be guided by the scriptural injunctions. So, there is Dharmashastra, how to conduct ourselves while we are living in this world for maintaining ourselves as well as for ultimate liberation from this material bondage. Everything is explained in Dharmashastra.

segments.key_quote: Chaitanya Mahaprabhu has instructed everyone you study these two scriptures Bhagavad Gita and Bhagavatam.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that the principles of Dharma are summarized in the Bhagavad Gita and Srimad Bhagavatam, and emphasizes the importance of devotional service to Krishna over serving illusion.
segments.transcript: Of course, now in Kali Yuga, we don't have time to study all the varieties of Vedic literature, especially the Dharma Shastras. There are 20 Dharma Shastras: Manu Smriti, Yajna Valkya Smriti, Parashara Smriti, like that, 20 great sages, they have compiled and every facet of human life, how one should actually conduct oneself, is explained there. But people have no time to study that, neither they are inclined to follow that. It is very difficult in Kali Yuga. Therefore, the principles of Dharma have been summarized in two scriptures, in two scriptures, the Bhagavad Gita and the Srimad Bhagavatam. These two scriptures, so Chaitanya Mahaprabhu has instructed everyone, you study these two scriptures, Bhagavad Gita and Bhagavatam. Both are called Krishna Katha, Krishna Katha. Bhagavad Gita spoken directly by Krishna, explaining the principles of Dharma very, very simple way, in a concise way, and Bhagavatam allows elaborately explains what is Dharma, Bhagavata Dharma. Bhagavatam explains what is real Dharma, Bhagavata Dharma, the principles of devotional service to Krishna. As in the previous session we discussed, we, our intrinsic nature or quality is to serve, so if we don't serve Krishna, then we will be engaged in serving illusion.
